awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Biomimetic Aramid Separators for Long-Lifetime Lithium-Sulfur Batteries
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project will be to address the key technological challenges of commercialization of lithium sulfur batteries, a promising solution for a new generation of electric vehicles (EVs).  Improving the extended battery capacity would increase driving range and reduce the cost.  We will develop a material that is an important element of the battery, using methods derived from studying materials like Kevlar(TM).  The material design process will include both new experimental techniques and novel computational methods that can be used to test batteries made by various manufacturers for many different EVs. An important part of this project will be the education of a new generation of entrepreneurs among graduate and undergraduate students.

The proposed project will address major issues in lithium sulfur batteries, a potential solution for high-capacity, high-discharge rate charge storage devices but currently limited by short cycle life due to the growth of dendrites and undesirable anode-to-cathode transport of lithium polysulfides. Resolution of these problems requires a new material combining ion-selective properties with exceptional robustness.  This project will utilize the structural design of cartilage known for an exceptional combination of mechanical and transport properties to engineer new ion-conducting membranes with the required properties. The team shall computationally recreate cartilage-like nanofiber networks and synthesize them with the desired parameters based on aramid nanofibers derived from Kevlar(TM) fabric.   These aramid nanofiber composites can potentially serve as separators in batteries, enabling up to 80% extension of their charge-discharge cycles. The new type of separators will be tested for prevention of dendrite growth and spontaneous diffusion of the polysulfides.  Special attention will be given to the development of scalable roll-to-roll processing of the aramid nanofibers separators and their implementation in high-capacity batteries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have high specific capacity that exceeds ten-year energy storage targets for many technological areas. However, lithium polysulfide diffusion from cathode and dendrite growth on anode drastically reduce their cycle life.  This collaborative University of Michigan, Elegus  Inc, and General Motors project  addressed these challenges by engineering ion-conducting membranes based on sequential layering of  aramid nanofibers to produce a new type of ultrastrong Kevlar-based cartilage-like membrane for advanced batteries for electrical vehicles.  Aramid  nanofiber membranes nearly completely suppresses the transport of lithium polysulfides because the polysulfide chains self-assemble on the surface of aramid nanofibers creating the layer of covalently bound negative charge that blocks the transport of poisonous lithium polysulfides. Importantly, it simultaneously facilitates the transport of lithium ions. The nanoscale size of pores combined with high strength and temperature resilience of enable efficient suppression of dendrite growth even at high temperatures. Tested under a variety of conditions, the battery cells with Aramid nanofiber membranes placed between cathode and anode exhibited capacity of 1245 mAh g-1 closely approaching the theoretical high for Li-S batteries.  Simultaneous mitigation of dendrite growth and polysulfide poisoning made possible Li-S battery with cycle life of 3500+ cycles with a capacity decay as little as 0.01% per cycle with cycling rates up to 3C.  Simplicity of aramid nanofiber synthesis and self-assembly of molecular components on their surfaces offer promising strategy for the design of high-performance materials for energy and water technologies.

As the result of this project, two patents were filed and approved.   One of the patents was licensed by Soteria Battery Group.  Elegus Technologies were able to produce initial prototypes an aramid based separators.   Elegus Technologies was acquired and the technology is being implemented.

 


Last Modified: 04/10/2022
Modified by: Nicholas A Kotov

Image
  • In collaboration with a start-up company Elegus Technologies, University of Michigan acomplished the goals of teh PFI proposal developing the scaled up manufacturing prototype for battery separators from aramid nanofibers.
    John Hennesssy and Siu On Tung
    Nicholas A Kotov
    Scaled-up preparation of aramid nanofiber separators

Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have high specific capacity that exceeds ten-year energy storage targets for many technological areas. However, lithium polysulfide diffusion from cathode and dendrite growth on anode drastically reduce their cycle life.  This collaborative University of Michigan, Elegus  Inc, and General Motors project  addressed these challenges by engineering ion-conducting membranes based on sequential layering of  aramid nanofibers to produce a new type of ultrastrong Kevlar-based cartilage-like membrane for advanced batteries for electrical vehicles.  Aramid  nanofiber membranes nearly completely suppresses the transport of lithium polysulfides because the polysulfide chains self-assemble on the surface of aramid nanofibers creating the layer of covalently bound negative charge that blocks the transport of poisonous lithium polysulfides. Importantly, it simultaneously facilitates the transport of lithium ions. The nanoscale size of pores combined with high strength and temperature resilience of enable efficient suppression of dendrite growth even at high temperatures. Tested under a variety of conditions, the battery cells with Aramid nanofiber membranes placed between cathode and anode exhibited capacity of 1245 mAh g-1 closely approaching the theoretical high for Li-S batteries. Simplicity of aramid nanofiber synthesis and self-assembly of molecular components on their surfaces offer promising strategy for the design of high-performance materials for energy and water technologies.

As the result of this project, two patents were filed and approved.   One of the patents was licensed by Soteria Battery Group.  Elegus Technologies were able to produce initial prototypes an aramid based separators.   Elegus Technologies was acquired and the technology is being implemented.
